'''Gender-critical feminism''', also known as '''trans-exclusionary radical feminism''' or its acronym '''[[TERF]]''', is a perspective that is critical of the concept of [[gender identity]] and therefore skeptical of [[transgender rights]] demands, especially [[gender self-determination]], as proposed by mainstream [[LGBT rights organizations]]. In contrast with most [[Third wave feminism|third]] and [[Fourth wave feminism|fourth wave feminists]], gender-critical theorists typically maintain that [[Sex assignment|sex assigned at birth]], which they often refer to as "biological sex", is immutable and therefore that [[trans women]] are not women.
These views have been described as [[transphobia|transphobic]] by other feminists and are opposed by most feminist organizations and by LGBT+ rights organisations.<ref name="Camminga B. 2020"/><ref name="Canada 110"/><ref name="Toutes des femmes"/> Gender-critical views have achieved a degree of prominence in the [[United Kingdom]], where they have been at the centre of a number of high-profile controversies. In several countries, the gender-critical movement has been linked to the [[anti-gender movement]],<ref name="Council of Europe 2021"/> and in some countries gender-critical groups have formed alliances with conservative, far-right, and anti-feminist organisations.<ref name="Butler idea of ‘gender’ backlash"/><ref name="CTV hate rise Canada"/><ref name="Alm & Engebretsen 2020"/>

== Background and terminology == Although trans people were been active in feminist movements in the 1960s and earlier,<ref>https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10714420802306726</ref> the 1970s saw conflict among feminists (especially early [[radical feminists]]) over the inclusion of trans women in feminism.<ref>{{Citation|last=Bettcher|first=Talia|title=Feminist Perspectives on Trans Issues|date=2014|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2014/entries/feminism-trans/|encyclopedia=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Spring 2014|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=13 April 2019|archive-date=28 March 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190328062920/https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2014/entries/feminism-trans/|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/08/04/woman-2|title=What Is a Woman? The dispute between radical feminism and transgenderism|last=Goldberg|first=Michelle|date=5 August 2014|work=New Yorker Magazine|access-date=1 December 2019|archive-date=13 November 2019|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191113031943/https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/08/04/woman-2|url-status=live}}</ref> In 1979, [[Janice Raymond]] published ''[[The Transsexual Empire]]'', criticising medical and psychiatric approaches to transsexuality, arguing instead that "the problem of transsexualism would best be served by morally mandating it out of existence," and accusing trans women of reinforcing traditional gender stereotypes.<ref>{{cite book | title=The Transsexual Empire: The Making of the She-male | last=Raymond | first=Janice G. | publisher=Teachers College Press | location=New York | isbn=978-0807762721 | year=1994 | edition=2nd | url=https://janiceraymond.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/The%20Transsexual%20Empire.pdf | access-date=24 May 2019 | archive-date=8 November 2019 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191108205024/http://janiceraymond.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/The%20Transsexual%20Empire.pdf | url-status=live }}</ref>
=== Trans-exclusionary radical feminism === {{For|more information on the word itself|TERF}} Trans-inclusive [[cisgender]] radical feminist [[blogger]] Viv Smythe has been credited with popularizing the term "trans-exclusionary radical feminism" in 2008 as an online [[shorthand]].<ref name="Miller 2018">{{cite web |url=https://theoutline.com/post/6536/british-feminists-media-transphobic |title=Why Is British Media So Transphobic? |last1=Miller |first1=Edie |date=5 November 2018 |publisher=[[The Outline (website)|The Outline]] |language=en |access-date=3 May 2019|quote=The truth is, while the British conservative right would almost certainly be more than happy to whip up a frenzy of transphobia, they simply haven't needed to, because some sections of the left over here are doing their hate-peddling for them. The most vocal source of this hatred has emerged, sadly, from within circles of radical feminists. British feminism has an increasingly notorious TERF problem. ... The application of the term has shifted somewhat over time to encompass most people espousing trans-exclusionary politics that follow a particular "TERF logic," regardless of their involvement with radical feminism.}}</ref><ref name="Smythe 2018">{{cite news |last1=Smythe |first1=Viv |title=I'm credited with having coined the word 'Terf'. Here's how it happened |newspaper=[[The Guardian]] |date=28 November 2018 |access-date=13 April 2019 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/nov/29/im-credited-with-having-coined-the-acronym-terf-heres-how-it-happened|quote=Due to a short series of blogposts from 2008, I have retrospectively been credited as the coiner of the acronym "Terf" (Trans Exclusionary Radical Feminists) ... a shorthand to describe one cohort of feminists who self-identify as radical and are unwilling to recognise trans women as sisters, unlike those of us who do.}}</ref> It was used to describe a minority of [[Feminism|feminists]]<ref name="Stryker TSQ">{{cite journal |last1=Stryker |first1=Susan |authorlink1=Susan Stryker |last2=Bettcher |first2=Talia M. |title=Introduction |journal=TSQ: Transgender Studies Quarterly |date=1 May 2016 |volume=3 |issue=1–2 |pages=5–14 |doi=10.1215/23289252-3334127 |doi-access=free }}</ref> who espouse sentiments that other feminists consider [[transphobia|transphobic]],<ref name="Lewis 2019">{{cite news |last1=Lewis |first1=Sophie |title=Opinion {{!}} How British Feminism Became Anti-Trans |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2019/02/07/opinion/terf-trans-women-britain.html |work=The New York Times |date=7 February 2019 |quote=If the idea that transphobic harassment could be "feminist" bewilders you, you are not alone. ... With time, the term TERF has become a catchall for all anti-trans feminists, radical or not.}}</ref><ref name="Miller 2018" /><ref name="Dastagir 2017">{{cite news |last1=Dastagir |first1=Alia |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/2017/03/16/feminism-glossary-lexicon-language/99120600/ |title=A feminist glossary because we didn't all major in gender studies |work=[[USA Today]] |date=16 March 2017 |access-date=24 April 2019 |quote=TERF: The acronym for 'trans exclusionary radical feminists,' referring to feminists who are transphobic.}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.lgbtqnation.com/2018/12/famous-lesbian-site-taken-anti-trans-feminists-now-lesbian-media-standing/|title=Famous lesbian site taken over by anti-trans 'feminists'. Now lesbian media is standing up.|last=Bollinger|first=Alex|date=19 December 2018|website=www.lgbtqnation.com|access-date=5 June 2019}}</ref> including the rejection of the view{{snd}}predominant in feminist organizations<ref name="Burns 2019">{{cite web |last1=Burns |first1=Katelyn |title=The rise of anti-trans "radical" feminists, explained |url=https://www.vox.com/identities/2019/9/5/20840101/terfs-radical-feminists-gender-critical |website=Vox |access-date=29 August 2022 |date=5 September 2019 |quote=“I don’t think American women are buying it,” she said, pointing out that nearly every major US feminist advocacy group is vocally pro-trans rights and inclusion.}}</ref>{{snd}} that trans women are women, opposition to [[transgender rights]],<ref name="Burns 2019" /> and the exclusion of trans women in women's spaces and organizations.<ref name="O'Connell 2019">{{cite news |url=https://www.irishtimes.com/life-and-style/health-family/transgender-for-beginners-trans-terf-cis-and-safe-spaces-1.3769653 |title=Transgender for beginners: Trans, terf, cis and safe spaces |last1=O'Connell |first1=Jennifer |newspaper=[[The Irish Times]] |language=en |date=26 January 2019 |access-date=24 April 2019}}</ref> Smythe has been also been credited with having coined the acronym ''TERF'', due to a blog post she wrote reacting to the [[Michigan Womyn's Music Festival]]'s [[Michigan Womyn's Music Festival#"Womyn-born womyn" policy|policy]] of denying admittance to trans women. Though it was created as a deliberately neutral descriptor, ''TERF'' is now typically considered [[derogatory]].<ref name="TerfOED">{{Cite OED|term=TERF|id=98002894|access-date=14 July 2022|date=June 2022}}</ref> == History ==
=== United Kingdom ===
Start around 2011.
In 2016, the [[House of Commons of the United Kingdom|House of Commons]]' [[Women and Equalities Committee]] issued a report recommending that the [[Gender Recognition Act 2004]] be updated "in line with the principles of [[gender self-declaration]]".<ref>{{cite report|url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/cm201516/cmselect/cmwomeq/390/39010.htm#_idTextAnchor213|title=Transgender Equality|last1=Women and Equalities Committee|date=8 January 2016|publisher=House of Commons|quote=Within the current Parliament, the Government must bring forward proposals to update the Gender Recognition Act, in line with the principles of gender self-declaration that have been developed in other jurisdictions. In place of the present medicalised, quasi-judicial application process, an administrative process must be developed, centred on the wishes of the individual applicant, rather than on intensive analysis by doctors and lawyers.|access-date=1 November 2021|url-status=live}}</ref> Later in 2016, in [[England and Wales]], a proposal was developed under [[Theresa May]]'s government to revise the Act to introduce self-identification, with a public consultation opening in 2018. This proposed reform became a key locus of conflict for the emerging gender-critical movement, seeking to block reform of the Act, with a number of groups such as [[Fair Play For Women]], [[For Women Scotland]], and [[Woman's Place UK]] being formed. The 2018 found a significant majority of respondents in favour of the GRA reforms,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/response-to-the-gender-recognition-act-2004-consultation |title=Reform of the Gender Recognition Act — Analysis of consultation responses |first1=Daniel |last1=King |author2=Carrie Paechter |author3=Maranda Ridgway |publisher=[[Her Majesty's Stationery Office]] |date=22 September 2020 |access-date=21 October 2021 |id=CP 294 |pages=8–9 }}</ref> however, in 2020, [[Second Johnson ministry|Boris Johnson's government]] dropped the reforms, instead reducing the cost of a gender recognition certificate and moving the application process online.
Another key locus of conflict for the emerging movement was the stance of LGBT+ rights charity [[Stonewall (charity)|Stonewall]] on trans issues. In 2015, Stonewall had begun campaigning for trans equality, with Stonewall head [[Ruth Hunt]] apologising for the organisation's previous failure to do so.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Gani|first1=Aisha|title=Stonewall to start campaigning for trans equality|url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/feb/16/stonewall-start-campaigning-trans-equality|access-date=31 May 2015|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=16 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150426042549/http://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2015/feb/16/stonewall-start-campaigning-trans-equality|archive-date=26 April 2015|url-status=live}}</ref> In 2019, the [[LGB Alliance]] was founded in opposition to Stonewall, accusing the organisation of having "undermined women's sex-based rights and protections" and attempting "to introduce confusion between biological sex and the notion of gender."<ref>{{Cite news |last=Hellen |first=Nicholas |date=22 September 2019 |title='Anti-women' trans policy may split Stonewall |work=The Sunday Times |location= London |url= https://www.thetimes.co.uk/article/anti-women-trans-policy-may-split-stonewall-wfv2rp5cx |access-date=13 February 2021}}</ref> ''Insert comments linking the Alliance to notable gender-critical feminists, to maintain its relevance to this article''.
[[Sheila Jeffreys]] (also in Australia section) <https://www.transadvocate.com/gender-critical-feminism-the-roots-of-radical-feminism-and-trans-oppression_n_14766.htm> Posie Parker ''Introduce Jeffreys and her theoretical position before the campaign, vis-à-vis NOTNEWS. It might be better to move much of the legal material to the judicial section, below, so that the gender-critical viewpoint is explained first (through representative figures) before the specific legal interventions''. 2019 saw the formation of the [[Women's Human Rights Campaign]] by [[Sheila Jeffreys]] and Heather Brunskell-Evans after Brunskell-Evans had been sacked from the [[Women's Equality Party]] as a result of her views on transgender people. The Campaign published a manifesto titled the ''Declaration on Women's Sex-Based Rights'', which argued that recognising trans women as women "constitutes discrimination against women" and called for the "elimination of that act."<ref>{{cite news |title=MPs urged by anti-trans ‘women’s rights’ group to eliminate ‘transgenderism’ and scrap Gender Recognition Act |url=https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2021/01/27/womens-human-rights-campaign-gender-recognition-act-inquiry-trans-transphobia/ |access-date=2 December 2021 |work=[[Pink News]]}}</ref><ref>https://www.womensdeclaration.com/en/declaration-womens-sex-based-rights-full-text/</ref>
2019 also saw a number of high profile court cases in the UK launched by gender-critical figures, including [[Maya Forstater v Centre for Global Development]] and [[Bell v Tavistock]]. ''Replace Rowling and Linehan with actual feminists commenting on the cases from a gender-critical perspective. This shouldn't be hard. [[Joanna Cherry]] should also be introduced here.''

Rowling]]<ref>https://www.cnn.com/2020/06/10/entertainment/jk-rowling/index.html</ref><ref>https://www.theguardian.com/books/2020/jun/11/why-is-jk-rowling-speaking-out-now-on-sex-and-gender-debate</ref><ref>https://www.scotsman.com/news/opinion/columnists/why-feminists-like-me-stand-with-jk-rowling-in-trans-rights-row-susan-dalgety-2910085</ref> have often been featured in social media gender-critical rhetoric. == Judicial activism by gender-critical feminists ==
Mostly UK, but also US and wherever else can be sourced. '''Note that to be DUE for inclusion, these cases need to be tied to actual feminism, either through participating figures (e.g., [[Sheila Jeffreys]], [[Julie Bindel]]) or concepts from gender-critical legal theory.''' We can't assume that every anti-trans argument ever made in court is relevant to this article.
In 2019, the [[Maya Forstater v Centre for Global Development]] tribunal case was launched by members of the gender-critical movement, crowdfunding over £120,000. Earlier that year, Forstater's consulting contract for the [[Center for Global Development|Centre for Global Development]] was not renewed after she made a number of social media posts describing [[trans woman|transgender women]] as men.<ref>{{Cite web|date=2019-12-19|title=Researcher who lost job for tweeting 'men cannot change into women' loses employment tribunal|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/home-news/maya-forstater-transgender-test-case-equalities-act-employment-tribunal-a9253211.html|access-date=2021-01-30|website=The Independent|language=en}}</ref> Forstater subsequently sued the Centre, alleging that she had been discriminated against because of her views.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/women/life/amfightingfor-therightto-saymen-cannever-bewomen//|title='I am fighting for the right to say men can never be women'|last=Gordon|first=Jane|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=April 23, 2021|access-date=April 23, 2021}}</ref> Forstater lost her initial case, with the judge ruling that her beliefs were not protected under the Equality Act due to their absolutism. However, in April 2021, the initial judgement was reversed, with the [[Employment Appeal Tribunal]] ruling that gender-critical beliefs were protected under the Equality Act.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Cross |first1=Michael |title=Appeal backs woman over ‘transphobic tweets’ 10 June 2021 |url=https://www.lawgazette.co.uk/law/appeal-backs-woman-over-transphobic-tweets/5108799.article |website=lawgazette |publisher=Law Society Gazette |access-date=17 June 2021}}</ref> A full merits hearing on Forstater's claim that she lost her employment as a result of these beliefs will subsequently be heard in March 2022.<ref>{{cite tweet|last=Forstater|first=Maya|user=MForstater|number=1416040503079018497|date=July 16, 2021|title=Breaking news (from Employment Tribunal case management hearing this morning) Forstater case to go to full hearing in March 2022 !}}</ref>
In October 2020, Ann Sinnott, at the time a director of the [[LGB Alliance]], initiated a legal case calling for a judicial review of the [[Equality and Human Rights Commission]]'s guidance on the [[Equality Act 2010]], crowdfunding almost £100,000 for legal fees. The Alliance believes that the specifics of the [[Equality Act 2010]] have been "misrepresented" by some organisations.<ref>{{Cite web|title=EHRC|url=https://lgballiance.org.uk/ehrc/|access-date=10 May 2021|website=LGB Alliance}}</ref> In May 2021 the case was found by the court to be [[Void (law)|unarguable]], Justice Henshaw stating that "the claimant has shown no arguable reason to believe the Code has mislead or will mislead service providers about their responsibilities under the Act."<ref>{{Cite web|date=6 May 2021|title=Judge throws out LGB Alliance founder's fight to ban trans women from women's spaces|url=https://www.pinknews.co.uk/2021/05/06/lgb-alliance-ann-sinnott-judicial-review-fails-london-high-court-equality-act/|access-date=10 May 2021|website=[[PinkNews]]}}</ref>
Later in 2020, the [[Bell v Tavistock]] case was heard by the [[High Court of Justice]]. Keira Bell had been prescribed puberty blockers by the [[NHS Gender Identity Development Service]] when she was 16 and then had a double mastectomy at the age of 20, which she came to regret. Bell subsequently sued to have prescriptions for puberty blockers to people under the age of 18 to be banned in England and Wales. The High Court initially ruled that minors under the age of 16 could not consent to puberty blockers and that minors aged 17 and 18 would need to seek court approval to determine their competency for the prescription, however, the ruling was overturned on appeal in September 2021.

== Controversies over freedom of speech and academic freedom ==
Conflict between gender-critical feminists and other feminists and transgender rights activists has resulted in controversies in which the principles of freedom of speech and academic freedom have been invoked. In Canada, conflicts have erupted over these issues in public libraries in Halifax, Toronto and Vancouver. In the United States, similar conflicts have erupted at university campuses in the broader context of the [[Culture wars]].
